reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reasons you should buy Grand Class Melee 260+ Classes -- With so many viable Skill combinations, it'll make you want to roundhouse kick a gorilla in the face.
Gigatross Games is awesome. -- Seriously. They're really awesome guys who actually give a damn about your feedback. Support 'em!
Best Local Multiplayer -- Yep, online multiplayer is on its way, but the local multiplayer with 3 of your best buds in one room is more exciting than beating Dolph Lundgren in an arm-wrestling match.
Kai Beam -- The moment you use this skill, you'll just know.

11/10 -- Would spam Flame Wisp again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An interesting multiplayer experience. While it's raw, I like the idea behind the class based changes and the chaos it causes, and the basic controls work and the gameplay can be fun with a group. The different classes play relatively differently and a lot of strategy can go into it. There's potential here.

THERE IS NO ONLINE MULTIPLAYER YET. This is local only, keep that in mind.

More First Impressions Here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pERgIg2ccyw

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A wonderful game that started as an Xbox Live Indie Game product for the 360.

It's a fasntastic local multiplayer experience, and the combat feels similar to that of Link to the Past, with some more RPG mechanics, and a class change after every round finishes.

Things to be noted, this game is currently local only, but online multiplayer is planned. An Xbox controller is also highly recommended, but not required as the controls are fully customizable.

Definitely give it a go, and play it with friends. It's a wildly fun experience and it will continue to recieve polish and balancing patches as it progresses through early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(My game time does not reflect time spent pre-Steam) This game follows in the footsteps of things like Towefall and Nidhogg. It's a brilliant and frantic arena fighter that borrows mechanics and aesthetics from Final Fantasy Tactics, Bomberman, and Link to the Past. Yes, that's right. It has a job-mixing system. *swoon*

Right now, it's local MP only, but it does have AI if you can't get anyone to play this with you. But, if you have anyone at ALL around you, just make them pick up a controller and play. It features that beautiful balance that makes it obvious and simple to pick up while still being deep enough to reward a lot of play.

There's the tactical level of learning how to parry and maneuever and use your abilities well. Then, there is the strategic layer of trying to adjust your job choices to what your opponents are using. Give it a shot. It's nearly impossible not to have some fun with it.

Great game, looking forward to future updates.

Bought this game because I was looking for a fun game to play with my friends. It doesn't disappoint. Even when there's no one else to play with, the bots are good sparring partners. I'm hoping for more fun game modes in the future as well as online multiplayer.

If you're looking for a fun game to play with friends, look no further. This game may only be early access, but it is a great game to destroy your friends at. Bottom line, 19/20 would become elementalists again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grand Class Melee 2 is an eight round competitive battle arena. Each round you progress up your class tree. Your new class will have one default ability, and you can select any previous class abilities you have used as your second ability.

The classes are basically melee, archer, and magic (which can split into healing or damage paths). The skills are reasonably diverse and there are many combinations you can employ each round. Needless to say this can create balancing issues - however the GCM2 team has it reasonably under control. On top of this they have a player based balancing feedback system.

The combat starts out reasonably simple. All class have the same basic attacks, a slash, which has a wider parry radius, and a charge, which sends the character forward with a low parry radius. Magic classes get many options for different kinds of attacks. Melee have more passive options, some attack skills, and some passives that augment basic attacks. Ranged classes get a variety of circumstantial speed/damage boosts as well as a good selection of different arrows.

Scoring options can be tampered with which can help to make different playstyles better. (for example the last man standing may get 2 points, most damage inflicted 1, most damage received 1).

The maps are procedurally generated and the camera pans infinately. The camera panning is quite complicated - and after several tweaks from the development team it works exceedingly well.

There were many planned features in the development stage that have yet to be realised. These include a way of the dark" class tree
date: of equal size to the current ("way of the light") path tree. Some of the planned skills were very interesting - including some necromancing elements. There was a parry shield planned
recommended: that prevented too many consecutive parries. And each class type (mage
hoursPlayed: melee and archer) had planned different charge attacks. Unfortunately none of these things have been realised as of yet - as far as I am awae they have been shelved to reconsider at a later date.\n\nThe price tag is a tad on the high side for current content - but this is generally speaking the case for early access games. This game is certainly conceptually sound
voteText:
fun and original - and therefor worth the buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think this is a great game and the fact that it is in early access just makes me wonder what else they are going to add. This game is fun and fast paced and is totally worth the 9.99 I paid for it however I do have one specific issues with it right now. That is a time commitment. The full experience, which is so worth it, is a time commitment that other fighting games don't have and I think people need to be prepared for that. the game plays in sets of 8 rounds. You go through and pick one of the starting classes and go up a very deep and intesne class tree. This is not  a casual game that you and 10 of your friends can all sit and get the full experience of like smash bros. This is a casual game that is a lot of fun and I would totally recommend it but it is not a party game. I urge you to download the demo before buying its free and gives you in my opinion a great feel for the game. This game is so worth 9.99.

EDIT: An update was released and I was notified by the developer that it should remember my audio video settings and it does.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

18 June 2015: i purchased this game. Since then, they released just two minor updates, so today (20 January 2016) i'm writing this review and i can't really recommend it.

If two small patches in eight months are enough for you... go for it, it's a good game and i'm not discouraging you in this sense, but personally, i don't like games managed in this way.

Edit: Hi dev. I removed the last point then, and again, i point out that my negative review is not related to the game, which is great, but just to the frequency of the updates.
